The '''Inflation Reduction Act of 2022''' ('''IRA''') is a landmark<ref>{{cite news |last=Dennis |first=Brady |title=As Congress funds high-tech climate solutions, it also bets on a low-tech one: Nature|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/08/14/nature-climate-solutions-inflation-reduction-act/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=August 29, 2022 |date=August 14, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Kaufman |first1=Anna |title=What is the Inflation Reduction Act 2022? Answering your common questions about the bill. |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/2022/09/23/inflation-reduction-act-2022-explained/8082806001/ |access-date=March 9, 2023 |publisher=USA Today |date=September 23, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230309055327/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2022/09/23/inflation-reduction-act-2022-explained/8082806001/ |archive-date=March 9, 2023}}</ref> [[Law of the United States|United States federal law]] which aims to curb [[inflation]] by possibly [[Deficit reduction in the United States|reducing the federal government budget deficit]], lowering [[Prescription drug prices in the United States|prescription drug prices]], and investing into domestic energy production while promoting [[clean energy]]. It was passed by the [[117th United States Congress]] and signed into law by President [[Joe Biden]] on August 16, 2022.

It is a [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|budget reconciliation]] bill sponsored by Senators [[Chuck Schumer]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[New York (state)|NY]]) and [[Joe Manchin]] (D-[[West Virginia|WV]]).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Everett |first=Burgess |date=July 27, 2022|title=Manchin and Schumer announce deal that includes energy, taxes |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/27/manchin-schumer-senate-deal-energy-taxes-00048325 |access-date=July 27, 2022 |website=Politico }}</ref> The bill was the result of negotiations on the proposed [[Build Back Better Act]], which was reduced and comprehensively reworked from its initial proposal after being opposed by Manchin.<ref>{{cite web |last=Zhou |first=Li |title=How Democrats plan to overhaul taxes, climate spending, and health care before the midterms |url=https://www.vox.com/23281547/build-back-better-joe-manchin-inflation-reduction-act |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=July 30, 2022 |date=July 28, 2022}}</ref> It was introduced as an amendment to the Build Back Better Act and the legislative text was substituted. All Democrats in the Senate and House voted for the bill while all Republicans voted against it.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" />

According to the nonpartisan [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) and [[United States Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation|Joint Committee on Taxation]] (JCT), the law will raise $738{{nbsp}}billion from [[tax reform]] and prescription drug reform to lower prices, and authorize $891{{nbsp}}billion in total spending – including $783 billion on [[Energy in the United States|energy]] and [[climate change in the United States|climate change]], and three years of [[Affordable Care Act]] subsidies.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite web |title=CBO Scores IRA with $238 Billion of Deficit Reduction |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/cbo-scores-ira-238-billion-deficit-reduction |access-date=2022-09-21 |website=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget |date=September 7, 2022 |language=en}} Note the ''original'' September 7 CBO estimates are $391 billion for climate action, $108 billion for health care, $281 billion from health savings, and $457 billion from tax reform, for a net total of $238 billion in deficit reduction.</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web |date=2023-06-07 |title=Repealing Inflation Reduction Act's Energy Credits Would Raise $663 Billion, JCT Projects |url=https://taxfoundation.org/inflation-reduction-act-green-energy-tax-credits-analysis/ |access-date=2023-06-12 |website=Tax Foundation |language=en-US}}</ref> The law represents the largest investment into [[Climate change policy of the United States|addressing climate change]] in United States history.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nilsen |first1=Ella |title=Clean energy package would be biggest legislative climate investment in US history |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2022/07/28/politics/climate-deal-joe-manchin/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=31 July 2022 |date=28 July 2022}}</ref> It also includes a large expansion and modernization effort for the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS).<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last=Rappeport |first=Alan |date=2022-08-04 |title=The I.R.S. says new funding won't mean more audits for middle-income Americans. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/04/business/irs-audits-funding-congress.html |access-date=2022-08-10 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>{{efn|A portion of the new IRS funding was rescinded in the [[Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023]].}} According to several independent analyses, the law is projected to reduce 2030 U.S. [[greenhouse gas emissions by the United States|greenhouse gas emissions]] to 40% below 2005 levels.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Laco |first=Kelly |date=2022-08-04 |title=Over 230 economists warn Manchin's spending bill will perpetuate inflation |date=August 1, 2022 |title=The Inflation Reduction Act Will Reduce Inflation |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/dpcc/press-releases/the-inflation-reduction-act-will-reduce-inflation |access-date=2022-08-05 |publisher=Senate Democratic Leadership}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=rbradley |date=2022-08-05 |title=Economists Letter to the U.S. Congress on the "Inflation Reduction Act of == Background ==
{{See also|Build Back Better Act|Build Back Better Plan}}
{{Joe Biden series|state=collapsed}}
The Build Back Better Plan was a legislative framework proposed by United States President [[Joe Biden]] between 2020 and 2021. Generally viewed as ambitious in size and scope, it sought to make the largest nationwide public investments in social, infrastructural, and environmental programs since the 1930s [[Great Depression]]-fighting policies of the [[New Deal]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Build Back Better Framework |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/build-back-better/ |access-date=2021-11-14 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref>

The plan was divided into three parts: one of them, the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021|American Rescue Plan]], a COVID-19 relief spending bill, was signed into law in March 2021.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web |last=Yarmuth |first=John A. |date=2021-03-11 |title=H.R.1319 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210226113259/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319 |archive-date=February 26, 2021 |access-date=2021-04-29 |website=Congress.gov}}</ref> The other two parts were reworked into different bills over the course of extensive negotiations within and among Congressional entities. The American Jobs Plan (AJP) was a proposal to address long-neglected infrastructure needs and reduce America's contributions to [[climate change]]'s destructive effects;<ref name=":02">{{Cite web |date=March 31, 2021 |title=Fact Sheet: The American Jobs Plan |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/31/fact-sheet-the-american-jobs-plan/ |access-date=March 31, 2021 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref> the American Families Plan (AFP) was a proposal to fund a variety of [[social policy]] initiatives, some of which (e.g. paid [[family leave]]) had never before been enacted nationally in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-04-28 |title=Fact Sheet: The American Families Plan |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/28/fact-sheet-the-american-families-plan/ |access-date=2021-04-29 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref>

The Build Back Better Act was a [[Bill (law)|bill]] introduced in the [[117th United States Congress|117th Congress]] to fulfill aspects of the [[Build Back Better Plan]]. It was spun off from the American Jobs Plan, alongside the [[Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act]], as a $3.5{{nbsp}}trillion [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|reconciliation]] package that included provisions related to [[climate change in the United States]] (centered around Senator [[Ron Wyden]]'s technology-neutral, tax incentive-first approach)<ref name="Dayen on Wyden 2022">{{cite web | last=Dayen | first=David | title=How Policy Got Done in 2022 | website=The American Prospect | date=September 26, 2022 | url=https://prospect.org/politics/how-policy-got-done-in-2022/ | access-date=August 28, 2023}}</ref><ref name="Weissmann 2023">{{cite web | last=Weissmann | first=Jordan | title=How the Inflation Reduction Act was really born | website=Semafor | date=August 16, 2023 | url=https://www.semafor.com/article/08/16/2023/how-the-inflation-reduction-act-was-really-born | access-date=August 28, 2023}}</ref> and [[social policy]], lowered to approximately $2.2{{nbsp}}trillion. The bill was passed 220–213 by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] on November 19, 2021.

In December 2021, amidst negotiations and [[Parliamentarian of the United States Senate|parliamentary]] procedures, Senator [[Joe Manchin]] publicly pulled his support from the bill citing its cost and a too-aggressive transition to clean energy,<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Seipel |first1=Arnie |last2=Hernandez |first2=Joe |date=2021-12-19 |title=Joe Manchin says he won't support President Biden's Build Back Better plan |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2021/12/19/1065636709/joe-manchin-says-he-cannot-support-bidens-build-back-better-plan |access-date=2022-08-31}}</ref> then retracted support for his own compromise legislation. This effectively killed the bill as it needed 50 senators to pass via reconciliation, and all 50 Republican senators opposed it.

In the summer of 2022, Manchin and [[Senate majority leader|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Chuck Schumer]] engaged in negotiations over a revised reconciliation bill with about $1 trillion in revenue from [[tax reform]], $500 billion in climate and health care spending, and $500 billion in deficit reduction.<ref name="Everett">{{Cite web |last=Everett |first=Burgess |title=Manchin's offer to Dems: Take a health care deal or try again later |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/14/manchin-rejects-climate-tax-elements-of-party-line-dem-bill-00046018 |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=Politico |date=July 14, 2022 |language=en}}</ref> However, Manchin announced abruptly on July 14, 2022 that he wouldn't support new climate spending or tax reform due to his fear that the bill would worsen inflation.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Cochrane |first1=Emily |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |date=2022-07-15 |title=Manchin Pulls Plug on Climate and Tax Talks, Shrinking Domestic Plan |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/14/us/politics/manchin-climate-taxes.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He later stated that he would be open to revisiting those elements a few months later, provided that inflation slowed meaningfully.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Weissmann |first=Jordan |date=2022-07-15 |title=Joe Manchin Just Knifed What Was Left of Biden's Agenda |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/07/joe-manchin-climate-spending-democrats.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=Slate Magazine |language=en}}</ref> Biden nonetheless conceded defeat on a climate bill, urging Congress to pass whatever Manchin would agree to (a slim, $280 billion health care bill that would acquire its revenue from allowing Medicare to negotiate prices and spend $40 billion on Affordable Care Act subsidies).<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Tankersley |first1=Jim |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |last3=Davenport |first3=Coral |date=2022-07-15 |title=Biden Concedes Defeat on Climate Bill as Manchin and Inflation Upend Agenda |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/15/climate/biden-inflation-climate-manchin.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="Everett"/>

Unbeknownst to nearly everyone in Washington, Manchin and Schumer reengaged in secret negotiations on July 18, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Lizza |first1=Ryan |last2=Daniels |first2=Eugene |title=Politico Playbook: How it really happened: The Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2022/08/08/how-it-really-happened-the-inflation-reduction-act-00050279 |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=Politico |date=August 8, 2022 |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, hours after the Senate passed the [[CHIPS and Science Act]],<ref name=":0"/> the two men released a statement announcing the $891 billion Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, which included climate spending and tax reform.<ref>{{Cite web |author1=Kevin Liptak |author2=Manu Raju |author3=Ella Nilsen |author4=Alex Rogers |date=July 28, 2022 |title=How secret negotiations revived Joe Biden's agenda and shocked Washington |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/28/politics/manchin-schumer-biden-deal/index.html |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=CNN}}</ref>

The sudden deal was widely regarded as a "shocker", as Democrats had voiced little hope for a revival of their climate and tax priorities, in addition to Manchin himself being rather pessimistic on the prospect of an expanded bill.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Manchin's latest shocker: A $700B deal |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/27/manchin-schumer-senate-deal-energy-taxes-00048325 |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=Politico |date=July 27, 2022 |language=en}}</ref>

As the revised bill made its way through the chambers of Congress, the new reality of Biden unexpectedly having a clear path to enacting substantial portions of his domestic agenda into law led to a wide reevaluation of the success of the [[Presidency of Joe Biden|Biden presidency]] thus far and was expected to give the President and his party a boost in the [[2022 United States elections|2022 midterm elections]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Biden suddenly is piling up wins. Can Dems make it stick? |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/09/joe-biden-legislative-wins-00050461 |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=Politico |date=August 9, 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Montanaro |first=Domenico |date=2022-08-12 |title=Biden's recent wins could give Democrats a boost heading into the midterms |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/08/12/1116745451/democrats-biden-midterms |access-date=2022-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Chait |first=Jonathan |date=2022-08-12 |title=Joe Biden's Best Week Ever |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2022/08/joe-biden-presidency-best-week-ever.html |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=Intelligencer |language=en-us}}</ref>

==Legislative history==
[[File:P20220816CS-0389 (52386878143).jpg|thumb|President [[Joe Biden]] signing the bill into law in the [[State Dining Room]] of the White House on August 16, 2022. (L-R) Senator [[Joe Manchin]] (D-WV), [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] Chuck Schumer (D-NY), Rep. [[Jim Clyburn]] (D-SC), Rep. [[Frank Pallone]] (D-NJ), and Rep. [[Kathy Castor]] (D-FL).]]
The Build Back Better Act, which passed the House on September 27, 2021, was used by the Senate as the legislative vehicle for this legislation. On August 6, 2022 [[Senate majority leader|Senate Majority Leader]] Chuck Schumer proposed an amendment which would replace the text of the previously passed bill with the text of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. This substitute amendment was later adopted.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Yarmuth |first=John A. |date=2022-08-08 |title=Actions - H.R.5376 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=http://www.congress.gov/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=www.congress.gov}}</ref>

Schumer's lead staffer, Gerry Petrella, recalls the surprise phone call came from Manchin's office just prior to the August recess and the breakthrough negotiations occurred on the final summer weekend.<ref>Emma Dumain. (28 July 2023). "Q&A: Former Schumer aide on IRA behind the scenes". [https://www.eenews.net/articles/qa-former-schumer-aide-on-ira-behind-the-scenes/ E&E Daily website] Retrieved 29 August 2023.</ref>

On August 7, 2022, following the [[vote-a-rama]], an unlimited marathon voting session on amendments, that lasted nearly 16 hours, the Senate passed the bill (as amended) on a 51–50 vote, with all Democrats voting in favor, all Republicans voting against, and Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] [[List of tie-breaking votes cast by the vice president of the United States|breaking the tie]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite web |title=Senate passes Democrats' sweeping climate, health and tax bill, delivering win for Biden |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/inflation-reduction-act-senate-pass-climate-healthcare-tax-bill/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=www.cbsnews.com |date=August 8, 2022 |language=en-US}}</ref> On August 12, 2022, the bill was passed by the House on a 220–207 vote, with all Democrats voting in favor and all Republicans voting against it.<ref name=":11">{{Cite news |title=House passes Inflation Reduction Act, sending climate and health bill to Biden |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/08/12/inflation-reduction-act-house-vote/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> On August 16, 2022, the bill was signed into law by President Joe Biden.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Maegan Vazquez |title=Biden signs Inflation Reduction Act into law |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/16/politics/biden-inflation-reduction-act-signing/index.html |access-date=2022-08-16 |website=CNN|date=August 16, 2022 }}</ref>

==Provisions==
Over a period of 10 years, the law is estimated to raise revenue from:<ref name="dem_sum">{{cite web |date=August 11, 2022 |title=Summary: The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/inflation_reduction_act_one_page_summary.pdf |access-date=August 12, 2022 |publisher=Senate Democratic Leadership}} Estimates from the [[United States Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation]] or [[Congressional Budget Office]], depending on the number.</ref><ref>{{Cite web |author=Manu Raju and Ali Zaslav |title=Sinema says she will 'move forward' on economic bill, putting Biden's agenda on the cusp of Senate approval |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/04/politics/chuck-schumer-economic-bill-saturday/index.html |access-date=2022-08-05 |website=CNN|date=August 4, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Kimball |first=Spencer |title=Passage of Inflation Reduction Act gives Medicare historic new powers over drug prices |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/12/drug-prices-passage-of-inflation-reduction-act-gives-medicare-historic-new-powers.html |access-date=2022-08-16 |website=CNBC |date=August 12, 2022 |language=en}}</ref>
* Prescription drug price reform to lower prices, including [[prescription drug prices in the United States#Solutions|Medicare negotiation of drug prices]] for certain drugs (starting at 10 new ones per year by 2026, increasing to more than 20 additional ones per year<ref name="KFF 2022">{{cite web | title=Explaining the Prescription Drug Provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act |last1=Cubanski|first1=Juliette|last2=Neuman|first2=Tricia|last3=Freed|first3=Meredith| website=KFF | date=22 September 2022 | url=https://www.kff.org/medicare/issue-brief/explaining-the-prescription-drug-provisions-in-the-inflation-reduction-act/ | access-date=19 January 2023}}</ref> by 2029)<ref name="Sachs 2022"/><ref name="Cutler p=e223630"/> and rebates from drug makers who [[Price gouging|price gouge]] – $281{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":7" /><ref name="Sachs 2022">{{cite journal | title=Understanding The Democrats' Drug Pricing Package |last=Sachs|first=Rachel |journal=Health Affairs Forefront | date=10 August 2022 | url=https://www.healthaffairs.org/do/10.1377/forefront.20220810.661571/full/ |access-date=5 October 2022 }}</ref><ref name="Cutler p=e223630">{{cite journal | last=Cutler | first=David M. | title=Medicare Enters the Pharmaceutical Purchasing Business | journal=JAMA Health Forum | publisher=American Medical Association (AMA) | volume=3 | issue=9 | date=2022-09-01 | issn=2689-0186 | doi=10.1001/jamahealthforum.2022.3630 | page=e223630| pmid=36218929 | s2cid=252035393 | doi-access=free }}</ref>
* Imposing a selective 15% corporate minimum tax rate for companies with higher than $1{{nbsp}}billion of annual financial statement income – $222{{nbsp}}billion
* Increased tax enforcement – $181{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=CFP® |first=Kate Dore |title=With 87,000 new agents, here's who the IRS may target for audits |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/09/with-87000-new-agents-heres-who-the-irs-may-target-for-audits.html |access-date=2022-08-10 |website=CNBC |date=August 9, 2022 |language=en}}</ref>
* Imposing a 1% excise tax on [[stock buybacks]] – $74{{nbsp}}billion
* 2-year extension of the limitation on excess business losses – $53 billion<ref name=":7" />

In the same time period, it would spend this revenue on:<ref name="dem_sum" /><ref>{{Cite news |last=Shivaram |first=Deepa |date=2022-08-12 |title=Democrats passed a major climate, health and tax bill. Here's what's in it |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/08/07/1116190180/democrats-are-set-to-pass-a-major-climate-health-and-tax-bill-heres-whats-in-it |access-date=2022-08-12}}</ref>
* Addressing domestic [[energy security]] and [[climate change]], including funding for drought resiliency in western states – $783{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" />
* Continuing for three more years the expansion of [[Affordable Care Act]] subsidies originally expanded under the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021]] – $64{{nbsp}}billion
* Changes to [[Medicare Part D]], low-income subsidies, vaccine coverage, and insulin – $44 billion<ref name=":7" />
* Increased funding for the IRS for modernization and increased tax enforcement, including the hiring of up to 87,000 new IRS employees – $80{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news |title=Democrats' $80 billion wager: A bigger IRS will be a better IRS |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2022/08/06/inflation-reduction-act-irs/ |access-date=2022-08-10 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

$663 billion of the law's climate action investments are embedded in the federal tax code.<ref name="Bravender 2022">Up from the CBO's original projection of $270 billion. {{cite web | title=Greenwire: Podesta, IRS get to work on climate law's tax incentives | website=Politico Pro|last=Bravender|first=Robyn | date=5 October 2022 | url=https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/eenews/2022/10/05/podesta-irs-get-to-work-on-climate-laws-tax-incentives-00060477 | access-date=8 October 2022}}</ref><ref name=":8" /> As part of the overall investment into [[clean energy]], the law created a [[green bank]],<ref name="Cherny 2022"/><ref name="EESI 2022"/><ref name="EPA About Page"/> extended the solar investment tax credit for 10 years<ref>{{cite web|last=Stevens|first=Pippa|date=July 28, 2022|title=Solar stocks jump as Schumer, Manchin announce climate spending deal == Projected impacts==

=== Economic ===

The CBO estimated that the Act would have no statistically significant effect on inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Inflation Reduction Act: Comparing CBO and PWBM Estimates |url=https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/issues/2022/8/5/inflation-reduction-act-comparing-cbo-and-pwbm-estimates |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=Penn Wharton Budget Model |date=August 5, 2022 |language=en-US}}</ref> The [[Penn Wharton]] Budget Model also estimated that the Act would have no statistically significant effect on inflation, and initially projected that it would reduce cumulative deficits by $264 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Senate-Passed Inflation Reduction Act: Estimates of Budgetary and Macroeconomic Effects |url=https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/issues/2022/8/12/senate-passed-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2022-08-15 |website=Penn Wharton Budget Model |date=August 12, 2022 |language=en-US}}</ref> Its second analysis, with a higher projection of total spending, does not include deficit reduction.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web |date=2023-04-27 |title=Update: Budgetary Cost of Climate and energy provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/estimates/2023/4/27/update-cost-climate-and-energy-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2023-06-12 |website=Penn Wharton Budget Model |language=en-US}}</ref>

The nonpartisan [[Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget]] analyzed the Act and concluded that the "deficit reduction, along with other elements of the bill, is likely to reduce inflationary pressures and thus reduce the risk of a possible recession."<ref name="CRFB 1">{{cite web |title=What's In the Inflation Reduction Act? |date=July 28, 2022 |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/whats-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=July 30, 2022 |publisher=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget}}</ref> It further estimates that the Act would reduce the [[National debt of the United States|federal deficit]] by $1.9{{nbsp}}trillion over a 20-year period. This figure includes the resulting savings on interest payments.<ref name="CRFB 2">{{cite web |date=August 3, 2022 |title=IRA Saves Almost $2 Trillion Over Two Decades |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/ira-saves-almost-2-trillion-over-two-decades |access-date=2022-08-04 |publisher=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget}}</ref>

====Home energy assistance====
The Act aims to decrease residential energy costs by focusing on improvements to home [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]]. Measures include $9 billion in home energy rebate programs that focus on improving access to energy efficient technologies, and 10 years of consumer [[tax credit]]s for the use of [[heat pump]]s, [[Rooftop solar power|rooftop solar]], and high-efficiency electric [[Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning#Energy efficiency|heating, ventilation, air conditioning]] and [[water heating]].

The Act includes a 30% tax credit ($1,200 to $2,000 per year) and different types of rebates (reaching $14,000) for homeowners who will increase the energy efficiency of their homes. In some cases, all upgrade expenses will be returned.<ref name="Iacurci 2022"/><ref>{{USC|26|25D}} and {{USC|26|25C}}</ref>

The Act expands select current incentives in a tier-based system, beginning in 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Rogers |first1=Jack|date=August 19, 2022|title=Inflation Reduction Act Doubles Tax Credits for Building Retrofits |url=https://www.globest.com/2022/08/19/inflation-reduction-act-doubles-tax-credits-for-building-retrofits/ |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=GlobeSt |language=en}}</ref> The Act specifies that commercial buildings must update efficiency by 25%, compared to a reference building, to qualify for $0.50 per square foot of tax credit for the first tier, increasing to a maximum of $5.00 per square foot for the final tier.<ref>{{USC|26|179D}}</ref> The tax credits also extend to single and multi-family housing, requiring 50% less annual energy consumption compared to similar units.<ref name=":03" /> Vincent Barnes, a senior vice president from Alliance to Save Energy in Washington, D.C, stated that these policies were meant to reduce energy costs and demand on the power grid.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ebeling |first=Ashlea |date=2022-08-08 |title=Inflation Reduction Act Is Big Win for Serial Green-Home Remodelers |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/climate-and-tax-bill-is-big-win-for-serial-green-home-remodelers-11659971356 |access-date=2022-08-21 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

====Energy production====
There are also funds allocated to national [[Sustainable energy|clean energy]] production. This includes the continuation of the production tax credits (at least $30 billion)<ref>{{USC|26|45}}, {{USC|26|45X}} and {{USC|26|45Y}}</ref> and investment tax credit ($10 billion)<ref>{{USC|26|48}}, {{USC|26|48E}} and {{USC|26|48C}}</ref> toward clean energy manufacturing, including [[Solar power in the United States|solar power]], [[Wind power in the United States|wind power]], and [[grid energy storage]]. ===Drug prices===
One of the most consequential aspects of this act is the increased negotiating power granted to Medicare. Before the enactment of the Inflation Reduction Act, Medicare was notably restricted in its ability to negotiate drug prices directly with pharmaceutical companies. This limitation often resulted in higher costs for both the program and its beneficiaries. With the new rule, Medicare now engages directly with drug manufacturers, aiming to secure more favorable pricing agreements. This development has the potential to significantly alter the landscape of drug pricing, especially for high-cost medications under Medicare Part D.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sullivan |first=Sean D. |date=March 2023 |title=Medicare Drug Price Negotiation in the United States: Implications and Unanswered Questions |url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jval.2022.11.015 |journal=Value in Health |volume=26 |issue=3 |pages=394–399 |doi=10.1016/j.jval.2022.11.015 |pmid=36503034 |s2cid=254522229 |issn=1098-3015}}</ref> The Congressional Budget Office projects the [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] drug price negotiations will save the government $98.5 billion over the next decade.<ref name="CRFB 1"/><ref name="The New York Times IRA drug announcement 2023"/> The savings will be used to increase [[Medicare Part D]] benefits.<ref name="KFF 2022"/><ref>Thread by Stacie Dusetzina, health policy analyst at Vanderbilt University. {{Cite tweet|number=1696533545081250278|user=DusetzinaS|title=Are you feeling down because the drug that you take isn't on the list that @CMSGov just released for price negotiations in #PartD? Gale]], who is also co-director of the TPC, comments that it is important to consider that the calculations by the JCT did not take into account the provisions in the Act that would extend premium tax credits for health plans for low- and middle-income taxpayers, provide households with tax credits for making their property more energy-efficient, and lower the price of prescription drugs.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-02 |title=Putting JCT's Score of the Inflation Reduction Act Into Context |url=https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/putting-jcts-score-inflation-reduction-act-context |access-date=2022-08-03 |publisher=Tax Policy Center}}</ref>

The [[Tax Policy Center]] estimated that the bottom 80% tax filers by income would receive a net benefit, if ACA premium tax credits (subsidies) are included. The 80th-99th percentile would incur a small cost (0-0.1% increase in average federal tax rate) while the top 1% would incur a 0.2% increase. The costs mainly are imposed indirectly as corporations facing higher taxes may reduce the wage increases or levels for workers; individual tax rates were not changed.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Inflation Reduction Act Primarily Impacts Top 1 Percent of Taxpayers|language=en-US|work=taxpolicycenter.org|url=https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/inflation-reduction-act-primarily-impacts-top-1-percent-taxpayers|date=2022-08-11}}</ref>

== Implementation and results ==
The Biden administration's main overseer of the Act's implementation has been identified as [[John Podesta]].<ref name="Kuttner 2023"/><ref name = "nyt 2022-09-02">{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Lisa|date=September 2, 2022|title=Biden, remaking climate team, picks John Podesta to guide spending|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/02/climate/john-podesta-climate-biden.html|access-date=September 5, 2022}}</ref>
=== Economy ===
Research from climate policy analyst Jack Conness has revealed that $106 billion worth of 154 climate-friendly tech manufacturing investments within the United States, have been announced by companies since the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act, creating 88,000 projected jobs {{as of|2024|03|27|df=US|lc=y}}; when considered together with CHIPS Act investments, the total comes out to 182 projects worth $263 billion creating 113,400 jobs.<ref name="Conness 2023">{{cite web | title=Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and CHIPS and Science Act Investments | website=Jack Conness | date=March 27, 2024| url=https://www.jackconness.com/ira-chips-investments | access-date=March 30, 2024|archive-date=March 30, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240330062048/https://www.jackconness.com/ira-chips-investments}}</ref>{{Update after|2024|05|31}} Conness found that due to the Act's incentives, [[North Carolina]] would receive the individual project with the most money ($12.6 billion from [[Toyota]] in battery plants), while [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] would host the most projects (24), the most new jobs overall (14,019), the second most jobs created by an individual project (3,350), and the largest dollar amount in overall investments ($15.8 billion, followed by North Carolina's $13.8 billion), and [[South Carolina]] would receive the individual project with the most jobs created (4,000 from [[Scout Motors]]). More of the Act's investments in dollars went to counties with majorities that voted for Donald Trump in 2020 ($74,272,150,000) than for Biden ($30,941,050,000). 71 percent of the Act's investments were in batteries, while electric vehicle investments made up 12 percent and solar investments made up 12 percent.<ref name="Conness 2023"/><ref name="Osaka 2023">{{cite news | last=Osaka | first=Shannon | title=The unlikely center of America's EV battery revolution | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=April 17, 2023 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2023/04/17/georgia-evs-battery-belt/ | access-date=May 7, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2023/04/electrify-everything-scope-data/ |first=Jesse D.|last=Jenkins |title=What "Electrify Everything" Actually Looks Like|date=May 2023|access-date=May 8, 2023|website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}}</ref>

In a November 2023 report the interest group Environmental Entrepreneurs and the research firm BW found 210 announced projects directly linked to the Inflation Reduction Act, in the first year since its signing. They stated that the projects would create nearly 403,000 jobs, more than 100,000 of which would be permanent.<ref name="E2 2023">{{cite web | title=Analysis: IRA-Related Clean Energy Projects To Create 403,000 Direct & Indirect Jobs; Add Billions To GDP | website=E2 | date=November 1, 2023 | url=https://e2.org/releases/analysis-ira-related-clean-energy-projects-to-create-403000-direct-add-billions-to-gdp/ | access-date=November 1, 2023}}</ref> According to editor in chief Jeff St. John of [[Canary Media]], "During the projects’ construction phases, assumed to last five years from project announcement to completion, the report estimates the creation of 142,300 direct jobs, 55,900 indirect jobs and 105,300 jobs induced by the direct and indirect workers spending their wages." More than 185,000 of these jobs would be in electric vehicles, 48,795 would be in battery storage, 42,100 would be in solar and wind power, 21,322 would be in clean fuels, and nearly 5,600 would be in electric power transmission and distribution.<ref name="Canary Media E2 report 2023">{{cite web | title=How many jobs is the Inflation Reduction Act spurring? A lot | website=Canary Media | date=November 1, 2023 | url=https://www.canarymedia.com/articles/clean-energy-jobs/how-many-jobs-is-the-inflation-reduction-act-spurring-a-lot| access-date=November 1, 2023}}</ref> The authors project that the Act would bring about "$156 billion added to U.S. GDP, $111 billion in new wages for workers, and more than $32 billion generated in tax revenue for federal, state, and local governments."<ref name="E2 2023"/>

According to the [[New Democrats (United States)|New Democrat]]-linked think tank [[Center for American Progress]], the Act, the CHIPS and Science Act, and the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act have together catalyzed over 35,000 public and private investments.<ref name="CAP 2023">{{cite web | last1=Ragland|first1=Will |last2=Koronowski|first2=Ryan |last3=Simhoni | first3=Shanee | title=Biden Administration Investment Tracker | website=Center for American Progress | date=June 20, 2023 | url=https://www.americanprogress.org/article/investment-tracker/ | access-date=June 29, 2023}}</ref> The Biden administration itself claimed that {{as of|2024|April|29|lc=y|df=US}}, the IIJA, CaSA, and IRA together catalyzed over $866 billion in private investment (including $395 billion in electronics and semiconductors, $173 billion in electric vehicles and batteries, $155 billion in clean power, $77 billion in the clean energy industry, and $38 billion in heavy industry) and over $537.4 billion in public infrastructure spending (including $70.2 billion in energy aside from tax credits in the IRA).<ref name="Invest.gov 2024">{{cite web | title=Investing In America | website=The White House | date=April 29, 2024 | url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/invest/ | access-date=May 4, 2024}}</ref>{{update after|2024|05|30}}
====Fiscal impact====
The law significantly enlarged the tax credit market. It includes significant tax credits for companies making products considered environmentally-friendly, but small companies tend not to pay enough taxes, so the law doesn't help them. The law allows such companies to sell their tax credits to larger companies.<ref name="Buffie 2024">{{Cite report|url=https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IF/IF12596|series=In Focus|number=12596|last=Buffie|first=Nicholas E.|date=February 26, 2024|title=Tax Credit Transfers and Direct Payments in the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022|publisher=Congressional Research Service}}</ref> The market is expected to reach $80 billion per year and help those large companies.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tankersley |first1=Jim |last2=Hirsch |first2=Lauren |title=In Biden's Climate Law, a Boon for Green Energy, and Wall Street |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/23/business/economy/climate-law-biden-tax-credits.html |access-date=29 November 2023 |agency=The New York Times |date=23 November 2023}}</ref>

In February 2024 ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''Energy Storage News'' reported that it was clear that companies were using the credits accorded by the law far more than was predicted. According to government officials they interviewed, the increase of revenue from improved [[Internal Revenue Service]] tax enforcement will be more than enough to cover the losses, so the deficit will still be reduced.<ref name=Jim>{{cite news |last1=Tankersley |first1=Jim |title=Why the Cost of Biden's Climate Law Keeps Going Up |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/02/08/us/politics/biden-inflation-reduction-act-cost.html?unlocked_article_code=1.T00.9Q50.YjKwcA0t5eJv |access-date=9 February 2024 |agency=The New York Times |date=8 February 2024}}</ref> The tax credits with the highest market value are for grid energy storage.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Murray |first1=Cameron |title=Energy storage tax credits in US priced highest among all clean energy types |url=https://www.energy-storage.news/energy-storage-tax-credits-in-us-priced-highest-among-all-clean-energy-types/ |website=Energy-Storage.News |date=16 February 2024}}</ref> The next month, the ''Times'' reported that the IRS had received from about 500 companies registrations of more than 45,500 projects attached to direct pay or possible small business sales of the IRA's energy tax credits, up from only about 1,000 in January.<ref name="Tankersley March 2024">{{cite web | last=Tankersley | first=Jim | title=Biden's Climate Law Has Created a Growing Market for Green Tax Credits | website=The New York Times | date=March 19, 2024 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/03/19/business/biden-climate-tax-credits.html | access-date=April 5, 2024}}</ref>

=== Environment ===
According to Rhodium Group and the World Economic Forum, in the first year of implementation, the Act had a significant impact on the environment. The Rhodium Group's expectations for [[Greenhouse gas emissions|GHG emissions]] reductions by the year 2030, relative to the level of 2005, moved from 17%-30% to 29%-42%, and to a 32%-51% decline by the year 2035. More than 170,000 green jobs were created. The sales of [[heat pump]]s exceeded the sales of [[gas boiler]]s for the first time in history. 15% of households now use a heat pump as a primary source of heating. The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] used dozens of millions of dollars to improve [[air quality]] and hundreds of millions for [[environmental justice]] and local climate plans. The [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] spent hundreds of millions for protecting [[coastal communities]] and [[coastal ecosystems|ecosystems]] from the impact of climate change. More than $1 billion is allocated to equitable access to [[urban tree]]s.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Broom |first1=Douglas |title=The US Inflation Reduction Act one year on – what's been achieved for the green economy? |url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2023/08/inflation-reduction-act-one-year-green-jobs/ |website=World Economic Forum |date=August 21, 2023 |access-date=24 September 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Taking Stock 2021: US Emissions Outlook Under Current Policy |url=https://rhg.com/research/taking-stock-2021/ |website=Rhodium Group |date=July 15, 2021 |access-date=24 September 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Taking Stock 2023 US Emissions Projections after the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://rhg.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Taking-Stock-2023_Rhodium-Group.pdf |website=Rhodium Group}}</ref>

The governors of four states, [[Florida]], [[South Dakota]], [[Iowa]], and [[Kentucky]], refused to accept decarbonization grants from the Act. The Act allows the forfeited money, $3 million per state, to go to the three largest metropolitan areas in each state instead, though cities such as [[Davenport, Iowa]] and [[Sioux Falls, South Dakota]] have still refused the money.<ref name="Lubach 2023">{{cite web | last=Lubach | first=Dave | title=Inflation Reduction Act Money Finds way to States that Refused Funding | website=Facilitiesnet | url=https://www.facilitiesnet.com/government_buildings/tip/Inflation-Reduction-Act-Money-Finds-way-to-States-that-Refused-Funding--51964 | access-date=August 16, 2023}}</ref><ref name="Aton 2023">{{cite web | last=Aton | first=Adam | title=How Biden steered climate money to red states | website=E&E News by Politico | date=July 19, 2023 | url=https://www.eenews.net/articles/how-biden-steered-climate-money-to-red-states/ | access-date=August 15, 2023}}</ref>

===Health insurance subsidies===
The Inflation Reduction Act extended the American Rescue Plan's modifications to the [[Affordable Care Act]]'s health insurance subsidies, namely the Advanced Payment for Premium Tax Credit, through 2025. The [[Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services]] attributed increases in ACA health insurance enrollment after the 2022 enrollment period in part to the IRA. The 2023 Open Enrollment period, the first one under the IRA, saw an increase in new consumers of 3,699,749, compared to the previous year's increase of 3,066,360. The CMS saw an increase in approvals for financial aid from the Act (90% of consumers compared to 2021's 85%, meaning the Act and ARP helped roughly 14.72 million people in calendar year 2022) and estimated national averages of $824 per year and 46% in IRA savings on premiums, in addition to finding that 1.4 million people making up to four times the poverty line were still able to access subsidies thanks to the ARP and IRA.<ref>{{cite report |author=CMS staff |date=January 25, 2023 |title=Health Insurance Marketplaces 2023 Open Enrollment Report |url=https://www.cms.gov/files/document/health-insurance-exchanges-2023-open-enrollment-report-final.pdf |publisher=Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services |access-date=May 3, 2024}}</ref> The 2024 Open Enrollment period saw 5,215,764 new consumers sign up for the exchanges, an increase of 31% from the previous year's 3,699,749. 92% of consumers (roughly 19.73 million people) received aid from the Act. The average annual premium savings figure now stood at $705 and 48%; the ARP and IRA had now helped 1.5 million people avoid subsidy ineligibility.<ref>{{cite report |author=CMS staff |date=January 24, 2024 |title=Health Insurance Marketplaces 2024 Open Enrollment Report |url=https://www.cms.gov/files/document/health-insurance-exchanges-2024-open-enrollment-report-final.pdf |publisher=Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services |access-date=May 3, 2024}}</ref>

==== Florida ====
The state received $3.75 million for [[Urban forestry|urban forests]] and nature conservation, $209,000 for fighting [[pollution]], and $78.7 million to protect the state from [[climate change impacts]] (the third amount is from the [[Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act]] and the Inflation Reduction Act combined).

However, the governor, [[Ron DeSantis]], refused to accept $346 million for rebates to homeowners who will want to [[home energy upgrades from public utilities|retrofit]] their houses for [[energy conservation in the United States|energy efficiency]], $3 million to fight pollution, a program for helping low income people buy solar panels as well as $24 million from the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act for improving [[sewage systems]] in rural areas.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Natter |first1=Ari |title=DeSantis Says No Thanks to $377 Million in Federal Energy Funds |url=https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/desantis-says-no-thanks-to-377-million-in-federal-energy-funds-1.1944205 |access-date=6 September 2023 |agency=BNN Bloomberg |date=11 July 2023}}</ref>  DeSantis later reversed course and attempted to reclaim some of the rejected home energy rebate funds.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/2023/12/18/desantis-seeks-energy-saving-rebates-in-apparent-change-of-heart/ | title=DeSantis seeks energy-saving rebates in apparent change of heart | date=December 18, 2023 }}</ref>

The money can go to local cities and authorities. Three cities in Florida accepted some amounts. Other states want to take the money forfeited by Florida for themselves, namely [[Rhode Island]] and [[Kentucky]].<ref name=Haberkorn/>

The funds for the rebates were requested by the Florida state energy office and the legislature, but DeSantis vetoed them. He is the only governor who did so. The program was intended to help people to lower their energy bills and create jobs. Half of the money would have gone to low-income households.<ref name=Haberkorn>{{cite web |last1=Haberkorn |first1=Jennifer |title=DeSantis tells Biden: Keep your IRA money |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2023/08/30/desantis-refuses-biden-climate-ira-money-00113397#:~:text=The%20governor%20also%20rejected%20%243,from%20the%20Bipartisan%20Infrastructure%20Law. |website=Politico |date=August 30, 2023 |access-date=4 September 2023}}</ref> Making a house more energy efficient can cut utility bills by 25% for an average family in Florida.<ref>{{cite web |title=How much does energy efficiency cost? |url=https://www.energysage.com/energy-efficiency/why-conserve-energy/cost-of-ee/ |website=Energy Sage |date=April 5, 2023 |access-date=6 September 2023}}</ref> Part of the money would have gone to [[weatherization]] of houses.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Calder |first1=Meta |title=Veto of energy-efficiency funding falls squarely on the poor |url=https://www.theinvadingsea.com/2023/08/21/inflation-reduction-act-florida-desantis-veto-energy-rebates/ |website=The invading sea |date=August 21, 2023 |access-date=6 September 2023}}</ref>

==== Texas ====

[[weatherization|House weatherization]], [[solar energy]], [[electric vehicle]]s, are advanced. House weatherization can save around $283 per year for an average family in Texas, while raising the value of the property and reducing air pollution in the same time. Some improvements can be made for free to low income households. The cost of an [[energy audit]] is reduced by 30% and some can even get it for free.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hutchings |first1=Kimberly |title=Beyond The Inflation Reduction Act: A Texas Guide |url=https://www.ohmconnect.com/blog/saving-money/beyond-the-inflation-reduction-act-a-texas-guide#:~:text=The%20Inflation%20Reduction%20Act's%20Energy,%24150%2C%20now%20through%20December%202032. |website=OhmConnect |access-date=6 September 2023}}</ref>

A third of Texas households can get a 100% rebate for installing a [[heat pump]] (generally costing US$8,000).<ref>{{cite web |last1=HENSON |first1=BOB |title=Heat pumps are catching on. New rebates, tax breaks may turbocharge the trend |url=https://texasclimatenews.org/2023/03/02/heat-pumps-are-catching-on-new-rebates-tax-breaks-may-turbocharge-the-trend/ |website=Texas Climate News |access-date=6 September 2023}}</ref> Forest protection is advanced, and farms that adopt climate-friendly practices get economic incentives.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Inflation Reduction Act Delivers Affordable Clean Energy for Texas |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Texas.pdf |website=The White House |access-date=6 September 2023}}</ref>

== Reactions ==
Senator [[Joe Manchin]] (D-WV) issued a statement for his support of the bill.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Luhby |first2=Tami |title=Manchin and Schumer announce deal for energy and health care bill |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/27/politics/schumer-manchin-deal-build-back-better/index.html |access-date=July 27, 2022 |work=CNN}}</ref> President [[Joe Biden]] also stated his support for the proposed bill.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=July 27, 2022 |title=Statement from President Biden on Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/07/27/statement-from-president-biden-on-inflation-reduction-act-of-2022/ |access-date=July 27, 2022 |website=The White House}}</ref> On August 4, Senator [[Kyrsten Sinema]] (D-AZ) issued a statement indicating that she would support the bill after striking a deal with fellow Democrats to change several tax provisions.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Democrats, Sinema reach deal on new taxes in Inflation Reduction Act |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/08/04/inflation-reduction-act-sinema/ |access-date=2022-08-05 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

Congressional Republicans have voiced unanimous opposition to the bill, claiming the legislation would do little to combat inflation, or would exacerbate it. Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] (R-KY) denounced the legislation as "reckless spending" and Ranking Member of the Senate Budget Committee [[Lindsey Graham]] (R-SC) called it "insanity".

In a letter sent to congressional leadership and touted by Senate Democrats, 126 economists including [[Robert Rubin]], [[Jack Lew]], [[Jason Furman]], [[Lawrence Summers]], [[Mark Zandi]], and [[Joseph Stiglitz]], wrote that the bill is more than fully paid for, lowers prices for consumers and will lower inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Betsy Klein |title=First on CNN: Top economists say Democrats' health care and climate package will put 'downward pressure on inflation' |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/02/politics/economists-democrats-package-downward-pressure-inflation/index.html |access-date=2022-08-14 |website=CNN|date=August 2, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=August 1, 2022 |title=The Inflation Reduction Act Will Reduce Inflation |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/dpcc/press-releases/the-inflation-reduction-act-will-reduce-inflation |access-date=2022-08-05 |publisher=Senate Democratic Leadership}}</ref>

In a letter sent to congressional leadership, 230 economists including [[Vernon L. Smith|Vernon Smith]], [[H. Robert Heller|Robert Heller]], [[Kevin Hassett]], [[James C. Miller III|Jim Miller]], and [[Larry Kudlow]], wrote that the bill will increase prices for consumers and will increase inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |last=rbradley |date=2022-08-05 |title=Economists Letter to the U.S. Congress on the "Inflation Reduction Act of 2022" |url=https://www.masterresource.org/inflation-reduction-act-of-2022/economists-letter-inflation-reduction-act-2022/ |access-date=2023-04-02 |website=Master Resource |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Laco |first=Kelly |date=2022-08-04 |title=Over 230 economists warn Manchin's spending bill will perpetuate inflation |url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/230-economists-warn-manchins-spending-bill-will-perpetuate-inflation |access-date=2023-04-02 |website=FOXBusiness |language=en-US}}</ref>

Tom Philpott, an agriculture journalist writing in [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'']], praised the bill's investments in climate-smart agriculture and remedies for USDA loan discrimination, but heavily criticized Sinema's deletion of the carried interest loophole modification and the lack of provisions to expand funding for the [[National School Lunch Act]] and improvements to child nutrition (as expressed in the original [[Build Back Better Act]]) and for [[soil erosion]] prevention programs (which enhance small-scale [[carbon farming]] and encourage a shift away from [[monoculture]]-dependent farming for [[ethanol fuel in the United States]]).<ref name="Philpott 2022"/>

Climate activists Miriam Nielsen, Raya Salter and Heather Tanana examined the Act's effects eight months after passage, and raised questions on whether the Act would provide tax credits and grants equitably, mentioning the home energy upgrade grants and the Biden administration's [https://www.whitehouse.gov/environmentaljustice/justice40/ Justice40 Initiative] for [[racial justice]], whether the Act would disproportionately help larger environmental groups with more resources rather than smaller ones, and how it would implement $4 billion in Western drought resilience grants and make accessing them easier.<ref name="Zentouro 2023 whole video">{{cite AV media|people=Nielsen, Miriam| title=What's going on with the Inflation Reduction Act?|location=New York, NY |type=YouTube video | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g9x3UeYOJn4|date=May 24, 2023|publisher=Zentouro | access-date=May 24, 2023}}</ref>

The [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] argued that despite continued acceptance of fossil fuels in the IRA, its climate mitigation policies would outweigh their impact ten times over.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Plumer |first1=Brad |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |date=2022-07-30 |title=Democrats Got a Climate Bill. ===Labor officials===
Some members of the trade union [[United Auto Workers]], including former vice president [[Cindy Estrada]], have obliquely commented to ''[[The American Prospect]]'' that the Inflation Reduction Act's implementation regarding [[prevailing wage]] requirements and [[collective bargaining]] rights (particularly at electric vehicle factories owned by startup companies) may be weakened, and if not properly implemented, the Act could be linked to poor hiring practices and working conditions.<ref name="Harris 2022">{{cite web | last=Harris | first=Lee | title=Industrial Policy Without Industrial Unions | website=The American Prospect | date=28 September 2022 | url=https://prospect.org/api/content/aff4b44e-3e71-11ed-9b46-12274efc5439/ | access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref> Other labor union representatives, from the [[AFL–CIO]], Southwest Laborers District Council, Ironworkers Local 848 and [[United Steelworkers]], told Reuters in March 2023 that investments announced due to the Act have not improved labor unions' ability to organize particularly in right-to-work law states, but that they were hopeful in pushing ahead.<ref name="Reuters right-to-work 2023">{{cite web | last=Groom | first=Nichola | title=Biden's clean energy factory jobs may elude U.S. union workers | website=Reuters | date=March 7, 2023 | url=https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/bidens-clean-energy-factory-jobs-may-elude-us-union-workers-2023-03-06/ | access-date=March 9, 2023}}</ref>
===Implementation criticisms (2023-)===
The ''Prospect''{{'}}s editor, [[Robert Kuttner]], commented in January 2023 that the Treasury Department's interpretation of the Act regarding electric vehicle leasing could also potentially undermine the Act's U.S. domestic supply provisions in favor of European or Chinese suppliers.<ref name="Kuttner 2023"/> Manchin expressed disappointment with the Treasury's new guidance and its more lenient provisions for foreign trading partners upon its release on March 31.<ref name="Bikales 2023"/> On December 18, he wrote a letter to [[Gene Dodaro]], head of the [[Government Accountability Office]], asking for a legal opinion on if Congress can overturn the Treasury guidance on Section 30D, on the basis that it is technically a proposal and not finalized, but is being enforced as the latter.<ref name="Cama 2023">{{cite web | last=Cama | first=Timothy | title=Manchin opens new front in war on Biden EV policies | website=E&E News by POLITICO | date=December 19, 2023 | url=https://www.eenews.net/articles/manchin-opens-new-front-in-war-on-biden-ev-policies/ | access-date=December 19, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite letter|last=Manchin|first=Joe|url= https://www.energy.senate.gov/services/files/5FEE5924-6E0B-47DE-97A6-FEE0B345BBE7|recipient=Gene L. Dodaro|date=December 18, 2023|subject=Request for legal opinion on Section 30D guidance|language=English|author-link=Joe Manchin|format=PDF|publisher=United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources|location=Washington, DC}}</ref>

On December 13, 2023, Manchin also expressed his disappointment with the Biden administration's implementation of his Section 45V tax credit<ref name="45V"/> for clean hydrogen after the draft guidelines were leaked, claiming it was "horrible" and too stringent beyond his intent for the credit.<ref name="Natter 2023">{{cite web | last=Natter | first=Ari | title=Joe Manchin Says 'Horrible' Hydrogen Tax Credit Rules Coming Next Week | website=Bloomberg.com | date=December 13, 2023 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-12-13/manchin-says-horrible-hydrogen-tax-credit-rules-coming-next-week | access-date=December 19, 2023}}</ref> Manchin later said he would bring a lawsuit against the Biden administration upon release of the guidelines. [[Constellation Energy]], the United States' largest nuclear power plant  operator, said it would pull back on green and pink hydrogen projects if the guidelines were released.<ref name="Kaufman 2023">{{cite web | last=Kaufman | first=Alexander C. | title=Democrats And Industry Are At War With Themselves Over A Controversial Energy Plan | website=Yahoo News | date=December 17, 2023 | url=https://news.yahoo.com/democrats-industry-war-themselves-over-130037079.html | access-date=December 22, 2023}}</ref> Staffers for Governor [[Gavin Newsom]] (D-CA) also asked the Treasury Department for an "alternative compliance pathway" that lifted emissions restrictions on the state's hydrogen hub, ostensibly to better align with their [[100% renewable energy]] adoption goal. <ref name="Cantú 2024">{{cite web | last=Cantú | first=Aaron | title=California's Dream of a Green Hydrogen Future Could Backfire | website=The American Prospect | date=May 9, 2024 | url=https://prospect.org/environment/2024-05-09-californias-dream-green-hydrogen-future-could-backfire/ | access-date=May 11, 2024}}</ref>

In April 2024, the Section 40B tax credit guidance was released. While biofuel producers, trade groups and [[United Airlines|United]] and [[American Airlines]] fully welcomed the guidance, farmers and lower-level ethanol producers said the guidance was too prescriptive and did not reflect the full range of agricultural approaches to climate policy, while environmentalists criticized the guidance for not going far enough to account for all lifecycle emissions from ethanol fuel.<ref name="Gallucci May 6 2024">{{cite web | last=Gallucci | first=Maria | title=Can corn ethanol really help decarbonize US air travel? | website=Canary Media | date=May 6, 2024 | url=https://www.canarymedia.com/articles/air-travel/can-corn-ethanol-really-help-decarbonize-u.s.-air-travel| access-date=May 6, 2024}}</ref> <ref name="Walter 2024">{{cite web | last=Walter | first=Cassidy | title=Agriculture and biofuel industries react to new rules for sustainable aviation fuel tax credit | website=Successful Farming | date=April 30, 2024 | url=https://www.agriculture.com/biofuels-industry-reacts-to-new-rules-for-sustainable-aviation-fuel-tax-credit-8641511 | access-date=May 6, 2024}}</ref>
